title.part: The Catalogue of Britten Manuscripts: Musical compositions of Benjamin Britten

identificationData.unitTitle: Britten Manuscripts: Musical compositions of Benjamin Britten

xhtml.p: Digital facsimiles are available online at http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts and a microfilm copy is available for reference at the British Library (shelfmark M. 881/1-5).
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
These manuscripts are normally held, on loan, at the Britten-Pears Library, Aldeburgh, but they are currently available at the British Library while the Britten-Pears Library completes building work.
All scores are wholly autograph, with the exception of some full scores which were prepared with the help of an amanuensis; these have been indicated as partly autograph.
Accepted by the Treasury in satisfaction of Capital Transfer Tax and allocated to the British Library.
Britten Manuscripts: Musical compositions of Benjamin Britten, British Library, Add MS 60593-60626

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Sinfonietta for Ten Instruments', op. 1

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60593
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Full score, for flute, oboe, clarinet in B flat, bassoon, horn in F, violin I, violin II, viola, violoncello, and double bass.
Autograph music manuscript, in ink, with annotations in red crayon and hinged and pasted-down corrections.
Manuscript dated 'June 20th - July 9th 1932' (f. 70), with Britten's signature on ff. 1, 2v and 70.
First performance: 31 January 1933, The Ballet Club (Mercury Theatre), London.
Folio dimensions (excluding smaller hinged and pasted-down additions): 346 x 255 mm. With a small tear at the top of folio 36.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Phantasy', quartet for oboe and strings, op. 2

xhtml.p: Unrestricted
Full score and parts.
First performance: Leon Goossens and members of the International String Quartet, 6 August 1933, BBC National. First concert performance: 21 November 1933, Music Club, St John's Institute, London.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Phantasy', op. 2 (score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60594
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Score, for oboe, violin, viola, violoncello. Autograph music manuscript, in ink, with hinged and pasted-down corrections.
Dated 'Sept.-Oct. 1932' (f. 1), and signed by Britten on ff. 1 and 33v.
f. 34 is a superceded folio containing 30 bars from the middle of the work.
Folio dimensions (excluding smaller hinged corrections): 355 x 255 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Phantasy', op. 2 (parts)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60595
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Parts for oboe (ff. 1-8), violin (ff. 9-25), viola (ff. 26-38), and violoncello (ff. 39-51).
Autograph music manuscript, in blue ink, with annotations in red ink and red and blue crayon, and with additional smaller folios hinged or pasted-down. Signed by Britten on ff. 1, 9, 26, and 39.
Folio dimensions (excluding smaller hinged and pasted-down additions): 355 x 255 mm. Repairs in clear adhesive tape to folio 39v.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Friday Afternoons', op. 7

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60596
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Title-page (f. i): 'Friday Afternoons / A Dozen School Songs', with Britten's signature.
Autograph music manuscript. The volume contains the following songs (numbered in red crayon), scored mainly for voice and piano:
I. 'Be-gone dull care!' (f. 1-1v). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, initialled 'BB' at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'July 30th 1935'.
II. 'A Tragic Story' (ff. 2-3). Words, William Makepeace Thackeray. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'Nov. 13th 1933'.
III. 'Cuckoo!' (f. 4-4v). Words, Jane Taylor. For 2 voices, ad lib, and piano. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'Nov. 11th 1933'.
IV. 'Ee-Oh' (ff. 5-6v). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'Dec. 19th-20th 1933'.
V. 'A New Year Carol' (f. 7). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning of the manuscript, and dated 'May 15th 1934'.
Folio 7v is an untitled manuscript fragment.
VI. 'I mun be married a Sunday' (f. 8-9v). Words, Nicholas Udall. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'Nov. 2nd 1933'.
VII. 'There was a man of Newington' (f. 10). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, signed at the head of the manuscript and initialled and dated at the end 'May 11th 1934'.
VIII. 'Angler's Song' (f. 11-11v). Words, Izaak Walton. Scored in pencil, without signature or date.
IX. 'The Useful Plough' (f. 12-12v). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'May 14th 1934'.
X. 'Jazz-Man' (f. 13-13v). Words, Eleanor Farjeon. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning of the manuscript, and dated 'Nov. 15th 1933 rewritten [obscure]'.
XI. 'There was a monkey' (ff. 14-15). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, without signature or date.
XII. 'Old Abram Brown' (ff. 16-18). Words anonymous. Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'Nov. 27th 1933'.
Folios 19-32 contain additional scored passages (in pencil, unless indicated) and another song ('Lone Dog'), as follows:

ul.li: 'Lone Dog (J. R. McLeod)', poem in typescript, with correction in pencil ('Irene') to poet's name (f. 28).
'No. 10 "Lone Dog"' (ff. 29-30). Scored in pencil, signed at the beginning and end of the manuscript, and dated 'Nov. 10th 1933'.
'Lone Dog' (ff. 31-32). Scored in ink, signed at the start of the manuscript. With correct attribution of text ('I. R. McLeod'). Not dated.

xhtml.p: First complete broadcast: 18 May 1949 (BBC Home Service).
Folio dimensions: 355 x 262 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Variations on a Theme of Frank Bridge', op. 10

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60597
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Short score (in pencil) for string orchestra. Autograph music manuscript, with Britten's signature to title page (f. 1). The manuscript is not dated.
The theme is taken from the second of Bridge's Three Idylls for string quartet, Op. 6.

Dedication (f. 1v): 'To FB - himself / His integrity / His energy / His charm / His wit / His tradition / His enthusiasm / His vitality / His symapthy (understanding) / His reverence / His skill / Our affection'.

ul.li: 'Var[iation] IV Allegro brillante' (ff. 8-9v). 'Aria Italiana' written at the head of f. 8v.

xhtml.p: First performance: 25 August 1937, Radio Hilversum, The Netherlands. First concert performance: 27 August 1937, Salzburg Festival.
Folio dimensions: 365 x 270 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Song for St Cecilia' [Hymn to St Cecilia], op. 27

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60598
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Words, W.H. Auden. Short score, for five-part unaccompanied chorus. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, with an addition in red crayon on f. 7v.

The work's original title ('Song for St Cecilia') is written across partially erased score which has also been struck-through (f. 1), and f. 1v is also struck-through, as are f. 8 and f. 8v. The score spans f. 2 - f. 7v.

Signed and dated by Britten on f. 7, recording the name of the ship on which the manuscript was drafted as Britten returned to England from the United States of America: 'April 2nd 1942 / M.S. Axel Johnson'.
First performance: 22 November 1942, BBC Home Service (pre-recorded 17 November 1942). First concert performance: 28 November 1942, Wigmore Hall, London.
Folio dimensions: 335 x 270 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Serenade' for tenor, horn and strings, op. 31

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60599
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Short score. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, with some revision of song titles in red crayon. The 'Prologue' and 'Epilogue' are not included.
Title page (f. 1): 'Serenade', in red crayon, written across a draft of the beginning (struck-through) of 'Dirge' (cf. f. 9). The draft continues (not struck-through) onto f. 1v.
'Pastoral' (ff. 2-3), title in red crayon. Words, Charles Cotton. A previous title ('Nocturne', in pencil) has been struck-through. Folio 3v: untitled rough notation.
'Nocturne' (ff. 4-6v), title in red crayon. Words, Alfred, Lord Tennyson. A previous title ('Ballad', in pencil) has been struck-through. The tenor part is marked 'PP' (for Peter Pears).
'Elegy' (ff. 7-8). Words, William Blake. The tenor part is marked 'PP'.
'Dirge' (ff. 9-10v). Words, Anon. Cf. ff. 1-1v.
'Hymn' (ff. 11-13v). Words, Ben Jonson. The tenor part is marked 'PP'. Dated 'April 2nd 1943' (f. 13v).
'Sonnet' (ff. 14-15). Words, John Keats. The tenor part is marked 'PP'. Initialled and dated: 'Snape / March 21st 1943 / BB' (f. 15).
First performance: 15 October 1943, Wigmore Hall, London.
Folio dimensions: 363 x 265 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: '[The] Beggar's Opera', op. 43

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60600
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff

Ballad-opera with words by John Gay and music realized from the original airs by Benjamin Britten. Full score, mostly in pencil, mostly autograph (apart from ff. 124-128v and ff. 139-140v which are in black ink, in the hand of Arthur Oldham, Britten's pupil and assistant).

Adhered to the inside front cover of the volume, a single sheet of 'Special Notes' (f. i, notes numbered i-v) by Rosamund Strode (Aldeburgh, May 1979). The notes refer to: previous page numbering of the manuscript (still evident); to differences between the manuscript and the published score in the numbering of songs; and to missing folios. British Library foliation of the volume (upper right corner of each recto) is continuous and does not take into account the missing folios referred to in the 'Special Notes'.
Missing folios:

ul.li: 3 folios are missing following f. 92v comprising Song 30 ('When you censure the age') and the opening 24 bars of Song 31 ('Is then his fate decreed, Sir?'). There is a note in pencil to this effect at the head of f. 93.
2 folios (referred to by Strode as 'three sides') are missing following f. 150 comprising Song 44 ('A curse attends a woman's love').

xhtml.p: The volume comprises:
Folio dimensions: 365 x 265 mm. Brown buckram binding. Not bound by the British Library.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Abraham & Isaac or Canticle II', op. 51

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60601
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Score, for alto and tenor voices and piano. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil (small additions in blue ink on f. 3v and on f. 9). Britten's initials on the title page (f. 1). Not dated.
Text: from the Chester Miracle Play Histories of Lot and Abraham.
First performance: 21 January 1952, Albert Hall, Nottingham.
Folio dimensions: 365 x 270 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'The Turn of the Screw', op. 54

xhtml.p: Unrestricted
Opera with libretto by Myfanwy Piper, after the novella by Henry James.
A short score (autograph) in a single volume, and a full score (partly autograph) in two volumes.
First performance: 14 September 1954, Teatro La Fenice, Venice (relayed by Radio Italiana, and by the BBC Third Programme).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'The Turn of the Screw', op. 54 (short score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60602
Unrestricted
Short score. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, with Britten's initials on ff. 5 and 47.

Dated (f. 85): 'Aldeburgh April 1st - July 23rd 1954'. However, Paul Banks, Benjamin Britten: A Catalogue of the Published Works (1999) remarks that the date of commencement is inaccurate, and also that 'the Prologue was added in late August or early September 1954' (p. 107).
The score is preceded (typescript, ff. 3-4) by 'The Characters of the Opera', 'Contents', and details of the first performance in the Teatro La Fenice, Venice, 14 September 1954.
Act I - ff. 5-45. (The title page to Act I precedes the 'Prologue', which begins on f. 6.)
Act II - ff. 47-85.
ff. 86v-105 contain draft material, including the 'Prologue' (ff. 88-89v).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'The Turn of the Screw', op. 54 (full score, Act I)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60603
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Partly autograph full score for Act I.

According to an editorial note (1979) by Rosamund Strode, pasted to the inside front cover (f. i), Britten's score in pencil was, at the composer's request, inked-over by Imogen Holst so that it could be used as a conducting score for the first performance, resulting in a music manuscript 'not fully characteristic of either hand'. With some subsequent corrections and additions to the score in pencil (see 'Final corrections', also in pencil, f. 1v).
Folio dimensions: 355 x 260 mm. Blue buckram binding. Not bound by the British Library. Binding weak, clear adhesive tape repair to f. 69 (side edge).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'The Turn of the Screw', op. 54 (full score, Act II)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60604
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Partly autograph full score for Act II.

In common with the full score for Act I, Britten's score in pencil was inked-over, at the composer's request, by Imogen Holst, so that it could serve as a conducting score for the first performance of the music; see the note (1979) by Rosamund Strode on the inside front cover of Add MS 60603 (f. i).
Folio dimensions: 355 x 260 mm. Blue buckram binding. Not bound by the British Library. Binding weak.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'A Midsummer Night's Dream', op. 64

xhtml.p: Unrestricted
Opera in three acts. An autograph short score ('sketches') in one volume, and a partly autograph full score in three volumes (1960), with later additions and annotations.
Text adapted by Britten and Peter Pears from the play of the same name by William Shakespeare.
First performance: Aldeburgh Festival, 11 June 1960, Jubilee Hall, Aldeburgh. First broadcast: 24 June 1960 (BBC Home Service), recorded 10 June at the dress rehearsal for the premire.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'A Midsummer Night's Dream', op. 64 (short score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60605
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Opera in three acts, in short score. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil.

Britten's initials appear on the title page to Act II (f. 39), and the manuscript is dated, in Britten's hand, at the end of the score: 'Sketches finished Good Friday 1960' (f. 110v). The folios following contain additional related material, including two brief passages (dated 1971) in a copyist's hand.
The volume comprises:

ul.li: buff paper front cover, entitled 'MSND' (f. i);
redrafted Lion's solo sung by Snug (f. 111);
redrafted Lion's solo sung by Snug (ff. 112-112v, struck-through);
unidentified passages in draft (ff. 113v-115v), including 'ill met by moonlight' (f. 113v);
passage from Act I, measure 77, beginning 'Thro' the forest I have gone' (ff. 118-119), all struck-through;
passage (partially struck-through) from Act I, 2 bars after measure 97 (f. 119v, identified in pencil at the foot);
Act III, 6 bars after measure 93 (f. 121, identified in pencil at the foot);
'last few bars of Bottom's Dream (concert version)' (f. 122);
in a copyist's hand, additional string parts (two bars) for Act II measure 34, and Act III measure 12, folio headed 'boosting the single harpist, Sept. 2/3 1971' (f. 124).

xhtml.p: Folio dimensions: 365 x 270 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'A Midsummer Night's Dream', op. 64 (full score, Act I)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60606
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Full score. Partly autograph music manuscript, in pencil, prepared for the publishers Hawkes & Son (London) Ltd.

There is a note in pencil (1978) by R[osamund]S[trode] at the foot of f. 1v, which copies the note by Britten (in faint pencil) to the copyist at the foot of the opposite folio (f. 2), concerning 'the length of slurs'.
Folio dimensions: 455 x 290 mm. Bound by Boosey & Hawkes.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'A Midsummer Night's Dream', op. 64 (full score, Act II)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60607
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Full score. Partly autograph music manuscript, largely in pencil (some parts for voices in black ink, in copyist's hand). Prepared for the publishers Hawkes & Son (London) Ltd.
Brief notation notes, and notes to the copyist, in Britten's hand, on ff. 1, 6v, 8, 15v, 19v, 22, 43v, 100v (struck-through), 118, and 119v.

Folio dimensions: 455 x 290 mm. Bound by Boosey & Hawkes. There is occasional smudging to some passages in ink on ff. 6 (and 6v), 9 (and 9v), 23 (and 23v), 68 (and 68v), 79 (and 79v), 86 (and 86v), 93 (and 93v). Ink blots on ff. 5, 65v, and 121v.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'A Midsummer Night's Dream', op. 64 (full score, Act III)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60608
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Full score. Partly autograph music manuscript, largely in pencil (with some parts for voices in black ink, in copyist's hand). Prepared for the publishers Hawkes & Son (London) Ltd.
Brief notation notes, and notes to the copyist, in Britten's hand, on ff. 1v, 11v, 13, 15, 15v, 17v, and 22.
Folio dimensions: 455 x 290 mm. Bound by Boosey & Hawkes. Very occasional light smudging of the parts in black ink. Ink blots on f. 20v, 56v, 66, 70, and 136.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'War Requiem', op. 66

xhtml.p: Unrestricted

A non-liturgical setting of the requiem mass, for soprano, tenor, and baritone solos, chorus, orchestra, chamber orchestra, boys' choir and organ. Texts: the Missa pro Defunctis (Latin), and poems by Wilfred Owen. Dedicated to Roger Burney, Piers Dunkerley, David Gill and Michael Halliday.
In two volumes: an autograph short score (including discarded draft fragments), and a partly autograph full score.
First performance: 30 May 1962, at the Festival to celebrate the Consecration of St Michael's Cathedral, Coventry (relayed by the BBC Home Service).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'War Requiem', op. 66 (short score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60609
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, signed by Britten (f. 2) and dated by him: 'Aldeburgh Dec. 20th 1961' (f. 68).
The volume comprises the complete composition, together with additional discarded draft material, as follows:

ul.li: title page, with Britten's signature, including reference to the first performance at the Festival to celebrate the Consecration of St Michael's Cathedral Coventry ([30] May 1962), textual sources, voices and instrumentation, and dedicatees (f. 2);
numbered list of six movements by title (f. 2v);
discarded draft fragments mainly untitled (ff. 69-101), several of which are specified in f. 102;
'Sketch pages for Exhibition at Imperial war Museum' - a list (typescript) of folios borrowed for exhibition (20 September 1974) and returned 7 July 1975 (f. 102).

xhtml.p: Folio dimensions: 365 x 270 mm.
The discarded draft fragments (ff. 69-101) are considerd by Philip Reed, in Mervyn Cooke, Britten: 'War Requiem'(1996), pp. 20-48, passim.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'War Requiem', op. 66 (full score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60610
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff

Partially autograph music manuscript, in pencil and in black ink, including the hands of two copyists (Imogen Holst and Rosamund Strode) - see Philip Reed, in Mervyn Cooke, Britten: 'War Requiem'(1996), p. 46.
Dated (Holst's hand): 'Aldeburgh, December 20th 1961' (f. 137), and annotated (in the same hand) with instructions to the copyist on ff. 101, 105, 120, 130.

ul.li: Title page 'Requiem aeternam', including brief note by Britten on the harp (f. 1).

xhtml.p: Not British Library binding. Folio dimensions: 545 x 340 mm. With smaller pasted-down ff. 97. 98, 131, 132, 135, and 136. There are brown 'splash' stains on f. 15-15v.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Symphony for Cello and Orchestra', op. 68

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60611
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Full score. Music manuscript, in pencil, on two sets of folios of different size bound together. Partly autograph.
Dated, in Britten's hand: 'Aldeburgh May 3rd 1963' (f. 74v). Also dated twice [by Boosey & Hawkes]: 'received 24.4.63' (ff. 1 and 30).

ul.li: Title and dedication: 'Cello Symphony / Score I / For Mstislav Rostropovich' (f. 1);

xhtml.p: Not British Library binding. Stamped on front cover: 'Boosey & Hawkes Hire Library'. Folio dimensions: 365 x 270 mm (ff. 1-29); 450 x 290 mm (ff. 30-74).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Curlew River', op. 71

xhtml.p: Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
A short score and a partly autograph full score.
Libretto: William Plomer, from the medieval Japanese N play Sumidagawa by Jr Motomasa.
First performance: 12 June 1964, Orford Church, Aldeburgh Festival. First broadcast: 21 June 1964 (BBC Third Programme).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Curlew River', op. 71 (short score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60612
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
An autograph short score, in pencil (ff. 1-44v), together with discarded autograph draft material (ff. 46-55).
With Britten's initials on the title page (f. 1).
The music in the draft material has been identified (and annotated in pencil by the Britten-Pears Library) at the foot of ff. 46, 47, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53, 54, and 55.
Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm. With a patch of scribble in blue ink at the foot of f. 46.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Curlew River', op. 71 (full score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60613
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
A partially autograph music manuscript, in pencil, with pasted-down additions in black ink for voice and chorus.
Dated, in Britten's hand: 'Score finished / Maundy Thursday / March 1964' (f. 396).

For tenor, two baritones, treble and bass voices, with the following 'Instrumentalists' indicated (f. 1v): 'Flute (doubling Piccolo) / Horn (in F - written in C) / Viola / Double bass / Harp / Percussion [further explication also given by Britten] / Chamber organ'.
Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm. Includes a number of smaller, pasted-down folios.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Songs & Proverbs of William Blake', op. 74

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60614
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
For baritone and piano. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, dated, in Britten's hand: 'April 6th 1965' (f. 24).

The title page (f. 1) shows faint traces of the work's original title ('Songs & Sentences') which Britten erased before writing 'Songs & Proverbs'. The texts, from William Blake, were 'selected by Peter Pears'. The title page is also signed by Britten and includes, at the top of the folio, his dedication to Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau: 'For Dieter - the past and the future'.

The rejected term 'Sentences' is also used (f. 1v) in Britten's list of the the texts, which alternate between passages from Proverbs of Hell (in the final extract, from Auguries of Innocence) and poems from the Songs of Experience.

ul.li: 'Sentences II': 'Prisons are built with stones of law...' (f. 4v);
for the revised section of 'A Poison-Tree', see ff. 10v-14 (of which, f. 13 is scored in blue ink);
'Sentences VII': 'To see a world in a grain of sand...' (f. 22);
f. 25-25v comprises draft material relating to 'Every Night and every Morn'.

xhtml.p: Britten has added a brief footnote to Rosamund [Strode], copyist, on f. 11v.

Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm (ff. 12 and 13 are smaller insertions). On the following folios, some staves have been extended in blue ink: ff. 3, 4, 4v, 5, 5v, 7, 7v, 8, 8v, 11v, 13 (which is also scored in blue ink), 14, 14v, 17v, 18, 18v, 20, 20v, and 22v.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Children's Crusade', op. 82

xhtml.p: Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
In two volumes, an autograph short score and a partly autograph full score.
Text by Bertolt Brecht. Set in German, and set separately in English (translation by Hans Keller).
First performance: 19 May 1969, St Paul's Cathedral, London (relayed by BBC Radio 3).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Children's Crusade', op. 82 (short score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60615
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, including discarded passages. Dated by Britten: 'November 10th 1968' (f. 20v).

ul.li: discarded draft passages (ff. 21-26v), identified in pencil at the foot of folios by Britten-Pears Library;
inserted verse, in English, with date '20 Nov. 68' at the head of the folio (f. 32);
continuation of voice parts set in English (ff. 33-36).

xhtml.p: Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm, except f. 11 (230 x 270 mm) and f. 14 (a small hinged addition to f. 13v).

Benjamin Britten, Children's Crusade (Kinderkreuzzug) Op. 82 (London: Faber & Faber, 1973). A limited facsimile edition of the short score, including twelve colour illustrations from a series of paintings based on the work by Sidney Nolan.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Children's Crusade', op. 82 (full score)

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60616
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff

A partly autograph music manuscript, in pencil, setting a text by Bertolt Brecht (translated by Hans Keller). Signed and dated by Britten: 'Aldeburgh October-November 1968' (f. 1), with an additional folio dated in a copyist's hand: 'Sept. '69' (f. 48).
The volume comprises:

ul.li: title page (f. 1), at the head of which Britten has recorded that the work was written for 'members of Wandsworth School choir and orchestra (director Russell Burgess) to perform on the 50th Anniversary of Save the Children Fund at St Paul's Cathedral, May 19th 1969', and described the work as 'A Ballad for children's voices & orchestra';
'Children's Crusade' (ff. 4-47v), including the English translation within the score;
an additional folio (f. 48) dated 'Sept. '69': 'Amendments to vocal line put into dylined full score used as German text Master Copy' (not in Britten's hand).

xhtml.p: Folio dimensions: 455 x 290 mm, except f. 48 (380 x 280 mm).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Third Suite for Cello', op. 87

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60617
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
An autograph score, in pencil, signed by Britten on the title page (f. 2), and dated 'Feb. 23 - March 3 1971 / Aldeburgh' (f. 12v).
The work is dedicated to Mstislav Rostropovich: 'For Slava' (f. 2). Rostropovich gave the first performance (21 December 1974) at Snape Maltings Concert Hall.
The volume comprises:

ul.li: title page, with Britten's signature and his dedication to Mstislav Rostropovich (f. 2);
the same revised passage of music in black ink (copyist hand), dated at the head of the folio: 'Jan. 74' (f. 3);
a note in pencil (f. 4), made by the Britten-Pears Library, highlighting two revised passages (f. 3 and f. 5);
the second revised passage, also the opening bars (f. 5);

xhtml.p: On f. 12, there are four indications of mood or expression that appear in both conventional Italian and in the Russian alphabet (capitals). Paul Banks (ed.), Benjamin Britten: A Catalogue of the Published Works (1999) notes (p. 143) that when Rostropovich visited Aldeburgh in January 1974 (which matches the date at the head of the revised passage on f. 3), he played the work to the composer and edited the published score.
Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm, except f. 1 (250 x 205 mm) and f. 3 (195 x 275 mm).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Canticle V 'The Death of Saint Narcissus', op. 89

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60618
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
An autograph score, in pencil, for tenor and harp, dated 'Horham July 1974' (f. 9).
The text is taken from the poem 'The Death of Saint Narcissus' by T. S. Eliot, and the work is dedicated to William Plomer.
The volume comprises:

ul.li: the text (typescript) of 'The Death of Saint Narcissus' [by T. S. Eliot] (ff. 1-2, with annotations in pencil);
title page, with Britten's initials, and his dedication: 'In loving memory of William Plomer' (f. 3);

xhtml.p: First performance: 15 January 1975, Schloss Elmau, Upper Bavaria (Peter Pears and Osian Ellis).
Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm, except f. 1 and f. 2 (290 x 205 mm).

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Sacred and Profane', op. 91

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60619
Unrestricted
Eight medieval lyrics for unaccompanied voices (SSATB). Autographmusic manuscript, in pencil. Signed, and dated 'Dec 1974 - Jan 1975' (f. 2).
The volume comprises:

ul.li: second title page ('Sacred & Profane / 8 Mediaeval Lyrics for 5 Voices') with Britten's signature, the dedication repeated, and a note at the bottom of the folio that the sequence of the lyrics should be attacca, breaking briefly between lyrics 5 and 6 if required (f. 2);
8. 'A Death' (ff. 13-16), dated 'Jan 9th 1974' (the year conflicts with dating elsewhere in the manuscript and it would appear that Britten intended '1975').

xhtml.p: First performance: 14 September 1975, Snape Maltings Concert Hall (the Wilbye Consort, Peter Pears conducting).
Folio dimensions: 380 x 280 mm, except f. 15 (115 x 180 mm) which is hinged and attached to f. 14v.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'String Quartet No. 3', op. 94

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60620
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Score. Autograph music manuscript, in pencil, with Britten's initials to the title page (f. 1). Dated: 'Suffolk-Venice - Oct. Nov. 1975' (f. 16).
The volume comprises:

ul.li: V 'Recit. & Passacaglia (La Serenissima): Slow' (ff. 13-16), dated 'Nov. 20 / 1975' at the foot of f. 15v;

xhtml.p: First performance: 19 December 1976, Snape Maltings Concert Hall (Amadeus Quartet).
Folio dimensions: 285 x 295 mm.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Music for the documentary film Night Mail

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60621
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff

Night Mail is a short documentary film produced by the General Post Office (G.P.O.) Film Unit about the London, Midland and Scottish Railway mail train making its journey north, from London to Scotland. Britten's contribution included the title music and the music for the end sequence, which was accompanied by a reading of verses written especially for the film by W. H. Auden, beginning 'This is the Night Mail crossing the border'.
Anautograph full score, in ink (with red and blue crayon), for flute, oboe, trumpet, percussion, harp, and string quartet.
Dated (in pencil), with Britten's initials: 'Jan. 12th 1936' (f. 20v).
The volume comprises:

ul.li: second sequence, incorporating various incidental sounds ('compressed air', 'sandpaper on slate', clanking and drilling noises, a whistle, hammering, and 'coal falling down a shaft') and the start of the commentary (ff. 5-6v);
passage for trumpet, scored in pencil (f. 21);
rhythmic notation (in pencil) of Auden's opening lines (f. 22);
trumpet part (two bars only), in pencil (f. 23);
trumpet part with other instruments (six bars), in ink (f. 24-24v).

xhtml.p: The music was recorded by an ensemble conducted by Britten, 15 January 1936. First broadcast: BBC TV, 16 October 1949. First concert performance: 7 November 1997, Conway Hall, London.
Folio dimensions: 355 x 260 mm.
For the full text of Auden's poem (dated July 1935), see Edward Mendelson (ed.), The English Auden: Poems, Essays and Dramatic Writings 1927-1939 (London: Faber and Faber, 1977), pp. 290-2.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Incidental music for The Ascent of F6

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60622
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Incidental music for The Ascent of F6, a stage play by W. H. Auden and Christopher Isherwood.
Signed by Britten on ff 1, 1v, 3, and 47. The volume is not dated.
Full autograph score, in ink (with some additions in pencil and red crayon), for voices (SATB), percussion, ukulele, and two pianos, as follows:

ul.li: signed title page, in red crayon (f. 1);

'Music to Group Theatre production of Ascent of F6' (a numbered list, in ink, of the sequence of compositions), and a note in pencil of the published scores available, stamped 'Boosey & Hawkes Rental Library' (ff. 1v-2);
text fragment, partly struck-through with red crayon (f. 42v);
'F6 Blues / ask the court to be cleared', beginning with Auden's text 'Stop all the clocks' (ff. 43-46v);

xhtml.p: First performance: 26 February 1937, Mercury Theatre, London. First broadcast: BBC TV, 18 September 1938. First broadcast with complete score: BBC National, 5 December 1938.

Folio dimensions: 360 x 260 mm, except for several small pasted down or hinged folios (ff. 22, 23, 26, 28, 30, 31, 32, 34, 35, 36, and 38. A number of folios have been repaired with clear adhesive tape.

For the poem beginning 'Stop all the clocks' by W. H. Auden, from which the lyrics of 'Caberet Song' (ff. 25-38) are partly drawn, see Edward Mendelson (ed.), The English Auden: Poems , Essays and Dramatic Writings 1927-1939 (London: Faber and Faber, 1977), p. 163.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Incidental music for The Dark Tower

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60623
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Incidental music for the radio play The Dark Tower by Louis MacNeice. Signed by Britten on the title page (f. 1). The manuscript is not dated.
Full score, autograph, in pencil (with additions in red crayon) for trumpet in C, percussion and strings, as follows:

ul.li: score, with 16 divisions indicated by Roman numerals in red crayon (ff. 2-12);
on f. 13v and f. iii are brief notes recording previous borrowings from the BBC Music Library.

xhtml.p: First performance: 21 January 1946, BBC Home Service.

Folio dimensions: 365 x 270 mm, except f. ii (25 x 70 mm) which is hinged and attached to f. i). Volume originally held by the BBC Music Library, with their ownership stamps on ff. i, 2, 6, 8v, and 12.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Juvenilia

xhtml.p: Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Two manuscript notebooks containing music written by Britten in his youth. The music comprises waltzes for piano and a Sonata in D Major for violin and piano.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Waltzes for piano

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60624
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Ten waltzes for piano, followed by a 'Waltz Duet' and a 'Petite Valse'. Autographmusic manuscript, in pencil (except for f. 1 and the first stave of f. 1v, which are in ink).

ul.li: Waltz 10, mis-numbered as '9' and corrected by Britten as '10' (ff. 14v-15);

xhtml.p: Re-bound (sewn) music manuscript notebook (A. Weekes & Co. Ltd., 14 Hanover St, London) with original soft covers. Dimensions: 295 x 235 mm.

In 1970, Britten published Five Walztes (retaining his original mis-spelling in the title), four of which were edited and revised from '10 Walztes' (1925) in manuscript, supplemented by a fifth Waltz (1923) from another manuscript source. See Paul Banks, Benjamin Britten: A Catalogue of the Published Works (1999), p. 3. See also, Christopher Mark, Early Benjamin Britten: A Study of Stylistic Evolution (1995), pp. 8-10. Mark reproduces Waltzes 1-2 and 5-9 (Appendix I, pp. 273-90). An arrangement of Waltz 6, Mark notes (p. 10), provided the 'scherzo' for Britten's Sonata in D Major for violin and piano (Add MS 60625) composed the following month.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: 'Violin Sonata in D Major'

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60625
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
For violin and piano, in score. Autograph music manuscript, in ink and in pencil.

Dated on the front cover: 'Begun March 1925'. The date on which the Sonata was finished is recorded on f. 13v and f. 17: 'April 6th 1925'. With Britten's (youthful) signature ('E B Britten') accompanying each date.
The notebook comprises:

ul.li: 'Adagio ma mon troppo' scored in ink (ff. 3v-5);
'Rondo' scored in pencil (ff. 10-14), finishing on f. 13v which is signed and dated;
Sonata violin part, scored in ink (ff. 15-17), signed and dated on f. 17.

xhtml.p: Re-bound (sewn) music manuscript notebook (A. Weekes & Co. Ltd., 14 Hanover St, London), with original soft covers. Dimensions: 295 x 240 mm.

Christopher Mark, Early Benjamin Britten: A Study of Stylistic and Technical Evolution (1995), p. 10, notes that the 'scherzo' (ff. 5-6) is an arrangement of Waltz 6 from '10 Walztes' (Add MS 60624). Four extracts from the Sonata are published in Mark, Appendix I, pp. 291-5.

identificationData.unitTitle: Benjamin Britten: Purcell realisations

xhtml.p: Digitised copy available on British Library Digitised Manuscripts: http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_60626
Restrictions to access apply please consult British Library staff
Three realisations of music by Henry Purcell. None of the manuscripts is dated.
1. Henry Purcell, 'The Golden Sonata' (Z 810), realised for two violins, cello and piano. Entitled 'Sonata IX', scored in pencil with Britten's signature on f. 1 (ff. 1-7v).
First performance: 21 November 1945, Wigmore Hall, London.
2. Henry Purcell, 'There's not a swain of the plain' (Z 587), scored in pencil, text over-written in blue ink, with Britten's initials: 'Purcell arr BB' (f. 8).

Text by Anthony Henley, inserted by Purcell (1693) into John Fletcher, Rule a Wife and Have a Wife (1624). Britten's arrangement was first performed by Britten and Peter Pears: 19 July 1943, Mayflower Barn, Jordans, Buckinghamshire.
3. Henry Purcell, 'Turn then thine eyes' (Z 425; text Anon). 'Purcell arr BB', scored in pencil (ff. 8v-9).
First performance (Britten and Pears): 13 March 1945, Salle de l'Ancien Conservatoire, Paris.
A note in pencil on the fly leaf (by Philip Reed, 3 June 1987) states that the manuscript has been incorrectly bound and indicates what the sequence of folios should be.
